entry.title: R Kernel Jupyter Notebook
entry.summary: We explore the R kernel for Jupyter notebooks through two simple examples.
entry.content:
R Kernel Test in Jupyter NotebooksÂ¶

Whenever I need to use R, my IDE of choise is RStudio which is awesome! Nevertheless, in this post I explore the R kernel for Jupyter Notebooks. In order to test it, I selected two simple but fun math cases.

We begin by loading the tidyverse.

In [1]:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ──
✔ ggplot2 2.2.1     ✔ purrr   0.2.4
✔ tibble  1.4.2     ✔ dplyr   0.7.4
✔ tidyr   0.8.0     ✔ stringr 1.3.0
✔ readr   1.1.1     ✔ forcats 0.3.0
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
In [2]:
# This is the version I am using.
R.Version()$version.string
'R version 3.5.0 (2018-04-23)'

Fibonacci NumbersÂ¶

We write a recursive function to get the Fibonacci Numbers. Recall that they are defined by \(Fibonacci(1) = Fibonacci(2) = 1\) and

$$ Fibonacci(x) = Fibonacci(x - 1) + Fibonacci(x - 2), $$

for \(x > 2\).

In [3]:
Fibonacci <- function(x) {
    
    ifelse(test = (x < 2),
           yes = 1, 
           no = (Fibonacci(x - 1) + Fibonacci(x - 2)))
}
In [4]:
# Let us compute the first 14 Fibonacci Numbers.
x <- 0:13 %>% sapply(FUN = Fibonacci)
x
  1. 1
  2. 1
  3. 2
  4. 3
  5. 5
  6. 8
  7. 13
  8. 21
  9. 34
  10. 55
  11. 89
  12. 144
  13. 233
  14. 377

Now we plot with the basic R function:

In [5]:
plot(x = x, 
     main = 'Fibonacci Numbers',
     xlab = 'x', 
     ylab = 'Value')

\(\pi\) EstimationÂ¶

We estimate the value of \(\pi\) using the relation (Basel Problem)

$$ \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{1}{n^2} = \frac{\pi^2}{6}. $$

Let us write an estimation funtion (using the great pipe operator %>%),

In [6]:
PiEstimateFromBaselProblem <- function(N){
    
    inverse.sq.sum <- 1:N %>% sapply(FUN = function(i) 1/(i)^2) %>% sum
                                     
    pi.estimate <- (inverse.sq.sum * 6) %>% sqrt
                                     
    return(pi.estimate)
}

We now want to plot the estimations ussing ggplot2.

In [7]:
# Set the estimation parameter.
N.max <- 1000

# Define a dataframe containing all the estimations.
pi.df <- data.frame(N = 1:N.max, 
                    Pi.Estimate = 1:N.max %>% sapply(FUN = PiEstimateFromBaselProblem))

pi.df %>% tail(10)
NPi.Estimate
991 991 3.140629
992 992 3.140630
993 993 3.140631
994 994 3.140632
995 995 3.140633
996 996 3.140634
997 997 3.140635
998 998 3.140636
999 999 3.140637
10001000 3.140638
In [8]:
# Now we plot the results. 
ggplot(data = pi.df) + 

    theme_light() +

    geom_line(mapping = aes(x = N, 
                            y = Pi.Estimate, 
                            colour = 'Estimation')) +

    geom_hline(mapping = aes(yintercept = pi, 
                             color = 'Pi')) +

    ggtitle(label = 'Pi Estimation From Basel Problem', 
            subtitle = sprintf('N.max = %i', N.max))
